August still feels neutered for mass consumption even to one barely familiar with the source.

Somewhat in keeping with its narrative's spectacle of deception, the comedown of this sugar rush of a film might not reveal the most nutritious consumption, but sometimes the messiest concoctions have a better taste.
Two hours of gloopy, insipid, narcissistic wish fulfilment ensues, alongside an uncomfortably extended promotion for dating site eHarmony.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The film comes alive in its second hour with the pairing of its two most charismatic players, becoming both funny (finally) and relatively enthralling ...
It's a shame the story's focus is so scattershot in jerking between the two leads' point-of-view.
The Battle of the Five Armies - by far the shortest of Jackson's Middle Earth films - is the most solid entry of this prequel trilogy.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The type of mainstream, commercial romance that's increasingly rare: one that never loses sight of actual tangible pain and hope in its beautifully portrayed characters.
There's much to admire with Bitch's absurdist deconstruction of patriarchal family politics, though more streamlining might have helped the attempted emotional catharsis.
Memory is the central theme of Marjorie Prime, a claustrophobic chamber drama with a neat sci-fi hook.
Its lack of nuance and persistent plotting issues frequently undermine much of the potential emotional heft.
Ellie Kendrick's towering performance - palpably conveying a life's worth of built-up anxieties and sadness - should prove star-making.
Large-scale nonsense executed strongly and with glee has its pleasures... the last few films have had their fun moments. This one has a few, too.
Emily Dickinson is played by Cynthia Nixon, in a nuanced turn that remains a vital anchor.
Suntan's somewhat predictable spiral into misery-by-way-of-toxic-masculinity nonetheless offers a few distinct aspects of note.
Cristian Mungiu's latest offers another suspenseful web of compromises, with an achingly sad figure at its centre.
You could superficially read Free Fire as a riff on the formula of Reservoir Dogs, but Wheatley's cinematic ancestry stretches back further and is far richer than that.
Larraín wraps his story of revolutionary poet Pablo Neruda within a fictional narrative; the approach is sadly unsuccessful.
A tender, kaleidoscopic portrait that captures the dreamy haze of a particular point in youth, in all its freneticism and fragility.
A fine showcase for the hypnotising Florence Pugh to veer from endearing puckishness to dangerously disturbed.
An authentic, complex, operatic, boldly expressive meditation on the circularity of time, alongside identity and love in all their forms.
Shinkai's effervescent young protagonists shine just as much as the glistening background details of every composition.

Iggy's survival means he's the film's anchor, and it's his captivating storytelling, full of both articulate reminiscences and daft flights of deranged fancy, that helps to overlook the film's overall lack of weight ...
Unlike many a behind-the-scenes portrait, Truffaut aims for affection and amiability for most of Day for Night.
This film does have one element keeping it from sinking fully into mediocrity: Cobie Smulders as on-the-run major Susan Turner.
A darkly comic study in sex, class and Japanese-Korean relations.
A thoroughly disturbing cinematic experience: non-fiction filmmaking by way of psychological thriller.
The relationship between music and motion proves the defining attribute of Edgar Wright's thrilling latest.
Rational and often hilarious, De Palma the raconteur is as brazen as his films.
There are glimmers of theoretically enjoyably daftness scattered throughout, but the trouble is there's about ten different films crammed in.
An impressive, unnerving debut feature from director Ben Young.
There's a leisurely pacing which allows for strong world-building and an attachment to the various weirdos of this world.
Brian Taylor exploits Nic Cage's penchant for the manic for all it's worth, but it's Selma Blair who steals the film.
It's like the beautiful sociopath child of American Psycho and Heavenly Creatures.
The plot's so rushed that it almost feels like it takes place within just an hour.
Returning director Wes Ball and cinematographer Gyula Pados subsequently get a lot more vibrancy from the film's apocalyptic clashes.
It's more of a case of the same few visual cues repeated ad nauseam, and ultimately little in the way of a message at all when it comes to its political bent.
For all the film's celebration of imagination as a tool for escape, the trajectory it follows is too uninspired.

[Masaaki] Yuasa's film is consistently entertaining, full of endearing characters, great humour, inspired character designs, and a propulsive energy even when there's a risk of overload with subplots.
movie_title: Lu Over the Wall (Yoake tsugeru Rû no uta) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The 100th film by Takashi Miike is a stylish, bloody action epic in the same vein as his 13 Assassins.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Like an intoxicating mix of Saturday Night Fever and Claire Denis' Beau Travail.
Michelle Pfeiffer, as tempestuous widow Mrs. Hubbard, is ultimately the only person to seize attention away from Branagh's 'tache.
Part heady romance, part coming-of-age tale, and one of the most beautiful recent examples of both.
A warm, quietly devastating drama that has plenty to offer for those open to something subtle.

The style mishmash - also including a bit of Mad Max - doesn't coalesce into anything substantial, nor do the flashy attempts at transgression and political commentary amount to more than insipidness.
Even if it's not especially scary, It is highly entertaining with excellent performances from its teen cast.
Moon Dogs has some appealing elements - including an impressive Anton Newcombe score - but its lame attempts at humour and general lack of imagination fail to charm.
Bolstered by an appealingly plucky protagonist at its centre, Napping Princess ticks most of the boxes for a crowd-pleasing anime adventure.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While its centrepiece section justifies a recommendation all on its own, the material that makes up the rest of Detroit is not without some problems.
It's definitely an actual ghost story, but, while it's haunting, it's certainly not a horror. Instead, as its rather perfect tagline posits, it's all about time.
Having previously helped skewer the American romantic comedy, Michael Showalter has created one of the sweetest, funniest modern examples of the genre.
The most philosophically profound movie featuring a flatulent corpse yet made.
James Gray's exploration into a driven individual's morality pairs lush, lyrically expressive imagery with rich emotional resonance.

The focus on the album's production allows for poignancy that comes from observing how therapeutic its creation becomes for Numan. The film's emotional centre, though, is the dynamic between Gary and his wife, Gemma.
movie_title: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Reynolds' giddiness at playing this insane, virtually indestructible mercenary has an infectious quality about it, and helps the gags that do hit to soar.
Undeniably goofy in tone but welcomingly sincere in spirit , for those who can get on Zemeckis's wavelength The Walk offers an array of pleasures.
All four leads are great in their own way, but Fiennes steals the show with his obnoxious, brash whirlwind.
Few films so heavy on bickering are quite as strangely relaxing as this deceptively slight gem.
Swing and a miss.
Not only is XXL a better film than its predecessor, it's a revelation as the most (casually) progressive mainstream movie of recent memory.
Samey, but some arresting sequences scattered throughout.
Perfectly pitched and bolstered by four beautiful lead performances, Our Little Sister, with the gentlest of touches, both breaks one's heart and makes it swoon.
Brooklyn is a touching romance and nuanced exploration of how perceptions of home and family shift as life throws us new opportunities.
A low-key but devastating drama with more raw authenticity than a hundred examples of Sundance landfill.
Running concurrently at all times with the black magic and shady goats is an affecting moral drama regarding the devastating roots that seep from seeds of distrust.
Riveting entertainment thanks to its three leads and evocative production design, Crimson Peak is also surprisingly heartbreaking.
Costa offers some oft-stunning compositions for his digitally shot, non-linear, draining foray into a world of shadows, dementia and delirium.
One of the finest American crime films in quite some time.
There's a pleasingly surreal melancholy to where the film goes, and then it all turns quite meta indeed.
The subject matter means The Wolfpack is inherently compelling for a while, but as a documentary it's an increasingly frustrating shambles.
Simultaneously fiery and farcical, it's a fitting final third for Wilder's 1950s hat trick that also includes Sunset Blvd and Ace in the Hole
Making vivid use of its Glasgow location and culture, The Legend of Barney Thomson has many dark comedy moments that work, and Carlyle shows some strong directorial chops.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sharp, snappy and often scathing, balancing a fine line between pointed barbs and broader laughs.
Concerned with the complexities of human decisions, actions and motivations, it turns internal woes we're all familiar with into the stuff of grand drama.
Its intoxicating power coming from just how alien it feels. It takes you to the past, but it seems like another universe.
With its tight, economic storytelling, Green Room keeps things simple and scary.
Like a spiky romantic comedy got stuck in one of the 1950s' bleakest visions of humanity - and it somehow all works magnificently.
One of the funniest comedies of manners since the heyday of Ernst Lubitsch.
The real highlight is the simultaneously bare-bones and elaborate modernist structures, best described as a blend of Lars von Trier's Dogville and Jacques Tati's Playtime.
You don't get the sort of outlandish motley crew of, say, a Roland Emmerich film. To be honest, that force of personality is sorely missed.
The Library Suicides concludes with the sort of narrative turn that actively sours what's come before it.
A series of funny and touching set-pieces that hardly feel particularly new, but are largely winning thanks to the strong cast.
A couple of the tales here are more palatable than others, but these can't quite transcend the film's overall feeling of mean-spirited pettiness.
The finest performance yet from Logan Lerman.
[Laura Albert] is a compelling storyteller, granting a tongue-in-cheek quality to support the documentary's rollercoaster journey concerning very real emotional traumas.
It's especially enjoyable to see comic stalwart Craig Robinson get his own sort of 'Punch-Drunk Love moment'.
It languishes in cliche, with characters that never shut up but have nothing to actually say.
A barbed satire which successfully walks a fine line between mockery and sincerity.
Unlike so many films aimed at kids, this one understands what it's like to see with the eyes of a child.
Gary Oldman's give one of his finest performances as Bex, who projects outward respectability under which lurks a creature of fragile masculinity and senseless rage.
A solid debut feature, with strong hopes for Australian cinema both behind and in front of the camera.
If this is indeed a farewell for Studio Ghibli, it's fitting that this modest, bittersweet treat is so concerned with deriving strength from the past.
Zootopia proves a successful amalgamation of disparate influences, much like its eponymous city.
Michael Fassbender and Jennifer Lawrence have rarely seemed so disinterested onscreen as they do for much of this.
There are still imperfections to be found in this Marvel offering, but when the highs are this good, it's hard not to temporarily give in to our new insect overlords.
In the film's floundering search for a decent laugh, the wackiness is upped to desperate levels in the hope that something - anything - might stick.
The major downside of Ilya Naishuller's debut feature is that while it looks like a video game, it also apes the worst qualities of the gaming experience.
In the end, a daft but interesting blockbuster becomes a daft and self-defeating one.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: ... Too Funny To Fail is one of the most entertaining comedy documentaries in recent history.
Clocking in at a crisp, succinct 80 minutes, The Babysitter is an enjoyable, breezy film that doesn't take itself too seriously.
It's fun, audacious, and everything good and pure about experimental indie filmmaking.
Creep 2 is the perfect scary movie for people who loathe traditional horror films.
Song of the Sea...is one of the most visually exciting and gorgeous films of the year.
...there's a sense of desperation to the proceedings, whereas the first film felt so light and surprising.
So many of the disparate elements of Tomorrowland work that it's kind of heartbreaking to see it saddled with an inconsistent script.
Disneynature's documentaries have proven to be exquisite to watch, but time and again, they falter, if not fail outright, at telling stories without getting in their own way.
...Cheatin' at least proves that though hand-drawn animation may be one of the oldest forms of the medium, it's plenty lively and colorful when its practitioners care.
Backcountry may zig instead of zag from its facile setup, but even the payoff doesn't stand out.
A profound and unshakable sense of unease pervades the entirety of Spring, from the opening scene all the way to the unexpected finish.
From the onset, Costner plays his incorrigible character less like a modern Gary Cooper and more like a new Archie Bunker.
...The Last Five Years, by tying itself to such a high-concept setup, feels more inevitable than invigorating.
Strange Magic is the kind of computer-animated film that makes you wish that hand-drawn animation could make a comeback, and soon.
The story of two working actors trying to get ahead in New York is, by itself, overdone; this movie barely tries to offer a new take on the familiar beats.
Into The Woods is excellent proof that we, as a society, need to rise up and stop Rob Marshall from directing a movie ever again.
It's easily Disney's best computer-animated film to date.
In the set-up, William Eubank acquits himself decently as co-writer and director. But the payoff is just too ridiculous to work.
There's a smattering of bright spots throughout, but overall, Alexander is such a neutral and neutered family film that it leaves behind no singular identity.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: ("Better than Sharknado 2!" may not be a desirable pull-quote, but there you are.)
One of the true monoliths of all cinema.
The Maid's Room is not as predictable as it initially seems, but it's far less impressive than its bombastic score and puffed-up script would believe.
...this new take on a quartet of mutated turtles who can take down faceless foes with the swiftest of ease is mostly uninspired, awkward, unfunny, and utterly charmless.
Behaving Badly is a contender for the worst film of the year...
...Get On Up is raucous and messy, but it's at least compellingly messy.
...this is a film that's so squarely content at being a movie just for kids...that it never rises above the dull and uninspired.
The Girl on the Train believes it's far more intelligent than it actually is, both in structure and in storytelling.
Tammy is...simply muddled and inconsistent, grasping for a collective audience sadface in between overlong, improv-heavy riffs.
...it's as if Joe Berlinger was sidetracked from delving into Whitey Bulger's crimes for a greater goal, offering up only a distracted and stretched-thin story in its place.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: ...the final third of Trust Me winds up being so misguided, compared to the overly familiar first hour, that the entire affair just feels noxious.
...this film plays like a talented cover band's version of your favorite song.
...while these disparate parts are compelling on a surface level, Algorithms is unable to cohere into a decent, coherent, and consistently paced whole.
From top to bottom, Inside Out is Pixar's best film since Ratatouille.
It's almost impressive how Michael Bay figured out how to make robots fighting each other the antithesis of fun.
Although Ant-Man is superficially shackled to the necessities of the MCU, it's snappier, lighter, and sharper than Marvel's more overblown films of late.
Self/Less is just tired; it's a direct-to-DVD knockoff that inexplicably got a few big names attached.
The film is undeniably flawed and messy, but there is a strong, passionate sense of heartbreak at its core, and the underlying message of hope and love manages to be both corny and aspirational
The end result is flaccid, more convinced of its intelligence than it should be, and painfully overlong.
Game Night manages to be both surprising and well-executed in its comic and suspenseful moments.

Clint Eastwood, with his new film The 15:17 to Paris, has gone out of his way to recreate the foiling of a would-be terrorist attack carefully. Unfortunately, he's done so in aggressively dull fashion.
12 Strong suggests a fascinating true story, but one that did not have the potential for feature-film power.
Paddington 2, like its hero, manages to surprise in its winning tone, its fierce cleverness, its heart, and its humor.
The Last Jedi is the best Star Wars film since The Empire Strikes Back, and is awful close to being its equal.

Though it stutters in its action-heavy climax, Thor: Ragnarok is perhaps the funniest Marvel movie yet, and suggests that the studio is beginning to understand the value of letting its stars cut loose.
At various moments, Coco is simply the most beautiful film Pixar has ever made, each shot a striking work of art.
Moana is proof of one of the slightly less-repeated axioms of storytelling: It's OK to use familiar tropes as long as you use them well.
Pinocchio is the greatest, most terrifying film in the Walt Disney Animation Studios canon.
Every scene in The Revenant may be remarkably staged, but feels rigorously planned.
Phantom Thread is perhaps [Paul Thomas Anderson's] most compelling, maddening, entrancing story to date.
[The Jungle Book] stumbles because the people involved aren't willing to fully commit to either making a near-shot-for-shot remake or going in a completely different direction.
A perfectly fine brand deposit in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
A 3D nightmare.
Finding Dory is a good movie, meaning that Pixar has a batting average of four for five when it comes to sequels.

The BFG is the latest example of Spielberg using the long take to experiment with digital technology, pushing himself as a filmmaker as much he pushes his characters or the audience through emotional experience.
It is, perhaps, a bit telling and awkward that the best parts of What Now? are less about Kevin Hart being funny and more about people reacting to Kevin Hart.
Moonlight takes the concept of the bildungsroman to its natural end point in ways that many coming-of-age stories don't.
...Laika's most impressive, miraculous work yet.
As no-frills as Shaun the Sheep Movie is, it's a winning and clever way to close out the summer family-movie season.
This may not be Pixar's greatest creative success, but simply as a piece of animation, it is their most gorgeous to date.
...a genuinely charming and funny film.
...no matter how hard he's tried, Vin Diesel continues to struggle in movies where he's required to do more than drive a car as fast as he can.
...the film loses its way as quickly as the climbers lose their footing.
... it's just nice to see a good M. Night Shyamalan movie again.
A movie that offends every moral sensibility but delivers few comedic rewards.
Viewers are taunted with the possibility of witnessing a possessed chicken.
Man of Steel is a very good superhero movie, but it's not necessarily a fun superhero movie.
This charming, witty and heartfelt film about the meaning of family might just remind you that there really are fresh voices at the movies.
It's a love story for characters that don't really deserve love, and a criticism of the shallowness of fame from a director who has always shunned it.
A lot of quality performances are undercut by a weak story, and Suicide Squad kamikazes its way into a clunky disappointment.
It's a path we've trod many times -- seriously, does every high-level CIA director have to be corrupt? -- but it's a path that holds up for a reason.
Nerve is all about our dependence on technology, but it will also make directors Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman's movie into a heavily dated time capsule for 2016.

Lights Out is one of the best bad horror movies to come out in some time. For a movie that is so dependent on routine jump scares, it's actually pretty fun when it lets its stringy, ghoulish hair down.
Even the twist feels like it comes up short of its intended emotional weight, and it's hard to think fans will remember this installment as anything special 10 years from now.

Music of Strangers explores that pensive relationship between art and politics, detailing the role of music as an expression and a search for meaning out of conflict, fortunately without getting on much of a soapbox in the process.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even though the heart of the film is fairly routine, Secret Life of Pets is bracketed with explicit acknowledgment of the unique relationship between loving owners and their pets.
Under Spielberg's hand, The BFG is heavy on charm and atmosphere, immersing the audience in a timeless world that blends the reality we know with a fantasy world we might imagine.
Altogether, The Legend of Tarzan may look great and try to take itself seriously, but it's really just a popcorn movie at heart. Treated as such, it's plenty of fun.
It's a lot easier to create a problem than to solve one. That's the fatal flaw of The Shallows, a well-intended thriller that stumbles across the finish line.
The Wolverine does hold great potential, but its best elements are underdeveloped.

Ultimately, Ghostbusters supports the argument that Hollywood would rather recycle a known product for a guaranteed buck than take any real chances. And that's too bad because the people involved are capable of better.
It's an action sports film with incredible visuals and an even more impactful message.
Antoine Fuqua's The Magnificent Seven won't make longtime fans forget the 1960 Sturges original, but it is a tense and dramatic western that feels like a perfect reflection of a violent 2016.
A contemplative and beautiful movie with just enough action to keep things interesting.
Wahlberg and Russell are solid in their roles, well complemented by the versatile Malkovich, and fans will enjoy seeing Leland in action after his previous work in Berg films.
It has a fun and original idea, strong, familiar voice-over performances and some clever writing and execution.
For anyone with any degree of appreciation for writing or literature or unsung heroes, "Genius" is definitely worth a look.
The Last Descent is tense and powerful, a signal that the carefree summer blockbuster season is officially over.
Even if the story is well-known, the content is worth seeing on the big screen.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There are several things to like about a quiet drama like Mr. Church. But the thing that feels most notable about director Bruce Beresford's story of a young woman and her unique father figure is the presence of Eddie Murphy in the title role.
Florence Foster Jenkins is a hoot, but it's also the saddest comedy you'll see this year.
The Wild Life is a harmless piece of second-tier animation that will pass silently in the night.

Little Men is the flip side of so many great coming-of-age films that bring their young protagonists into an awakened state via a rocky journey. Sometimes maturity and perspective comes at a cost that doesn't deliver a happy ending.
Fassbender and Vikander are both powerful in their roles, and even in a comparatively small amount of screen time, Weisz is commanding.
The most obvious problem with Adventure to the Moon is its primitive animation. The quality is frequently rough and at a level usually found on straight-to-DVD releases.
movie_title: Space Dogs: Adventure to the Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Southside With You is more than a carefree portrait of young love, but how much more may depend on your ability to keep your political perspectives at arm's length.
When you add up all these parts, Ben-Hur fails to answer the question everyone will take to the theater: Why?
Kubo and the Two Strings is a very cool piece of animation. If you are a fan of animation, particularly the stop-motion variety, put this one at the top of your list.

It's nice to have a movie like Sully come around every once in a while. Director Clint Eastwood's re-creation of 2009's "Miracle on the Hudson" is the kind of story that will restore some of your faith in humanity.
Dark Horse is the equestrian equivalent of a D-League affiliate making it to the NBA Finals.
April is a creative and compelling film set in an alternate historic reality that imagines different results from the Industrial Revolution. It's essentially a steampunk fantasy with subtitles.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It will make you laugh but leave you wishing the whole package was a little better.

Midnight Special is good enough to make you cheer for it, but it stumbles when it comes time to take the winning shot. It features strong performances, a suspenseful tone and just enough ambiguity to get it in trouble.
Overall, though, Saturday's Warrior flirts with these ideas more than it explores them, and the final product is more nostalgic than moving.

The first film was a showcase for Toula and her story, with her crazy family as a charming backdrop. But Greek Wedding 2 tries too hard to cover too much, and the result is a film that feels overcooked in places and far too underdone in others.
The bottom line on Batman v Superman, then, is that it is an entertaining but flawed step up from "Man of Steel," and is a dark, action-packed setup for future Justice League films.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It has a few nice moments but feels more like an exercise in extending a narrative than a vehicle for building a dramatic conclusion.
The individual parts don't always work, but the whole gets the job done in a satisfying way.

Courtroom dramas are notorious for long-winded speeches and preachy content, but God's Not Dead 2 has an especially nasty habit of using lengthy speeches for tedious exposition. It often feels like you're watching someone read an op-ed piece to you.
In a film with strengths and weaknesses, Singing with Angels picks the right time to let its strengths shine.
10 Cloverfield Lane is a fun and frightening blend of horror, suspense and science fiction that keeps twisting and turning right up to the final credits.

As cool as those visuals may be, the thing that will resonate most with viewers is The Boy and the Beast's messages about family and finding the personal strength to resist the darkness within our hearts.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A rich blend of story, message and entertainment.
The result is a poignant story that will make you think and a beautiful landscape that will make you marvel.
Eddie the Eagle might just inspire you whether you want it to or not.
Gods of Egypt is much more interested in spectacle than substance, which would be great if its spectacle were more substantial.
Director Cyrus Nowrasteh works with an effective, understated tone that respects his story enough to let it speak for itself. Greaves-Neal's performance is a perfect fit for this style.
The Jungle Book is one of the most effective blends of computer-generated imagery and live action in recent memory.
It does a lot to make you think, but The Next Cut has a much harder time persuading you what to think about anything in particular.
Winter's War is a kind of poor man's Lord of the Rings, only if you swapped out Sauron with Elsa from Disney's Frozen.
Director Duncan Jones has made a noble attempt to fashion a cinematic world of his own, but his characters lack the depth and substance to give the film any gravitas.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows isn't so much a movie as it is a product with a really long name. It's 112 minutes of CGI mayhem, snappy catch phrases and a standard hero plot, all pieced together in a familiar formula.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Played masterfully by Susan Sarandon, Marnie is the centerpiece of The Meddler, a subtle, poignant and often funny film about moving on.
Whit Stillman skillfully weaves the threads of a story that is more witty than audiences might expect.
Fun but quickly forgettable.

For all the mess Apocalypse makes, the quality of its cast and characters, combined with the strength of the stories that have come before, will at least make Singer's new film entertaining as a quick fix.

If you are content to spend as much time in Middle Earth as possible, you'll have plenty of fun with this year's installment. But if you're a stickler for literary accuracy and pacing, the offering may prove only slightly less frustrating.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As bland as its uninspired title.
The plot is pretty simple. The real question is can it entertain the kids, and the answer depends on how receptive your children are to gyrating dance sequences set to covers of old pop standards.
It is a portrait of a player and his country, and even if the film takes a conventional route to its destination, fans of the game should still enjoy it.
The sum of the effort is a sincere film that offers insight in surprising areas.
It isn't a perfect effort, but it's plenty to reach summer blockbuster status, and Civil War will leave fans salivating for the next installment in the series.
Nalwanga's performance is well supported by veterans Oyelowo and Wyong'o.
It's a setup for an underdog buddy comedy with potential, but Ratchet and his robo-pal get lost in the shuffle of the film's plot.
The cast does its best with what they are given, even if what they are given are often flat jokes.
It's a quality piece of family animation with a fun finish that hits a few themes you might expect and a few that will surprise you.
For many Burton fans, it will feel like a welcome return to form.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the animation world's cinematic highlights for 2016.
Sadly, Spirit of the Game is frequently undone by stiff acting and troubled storytelling.
Its story may not change one's life, but "Kedi" captures a fascinating portrait of a city and a people from an animal most would disregard.

This is a fun, fun movie. It's also a violent movie - the high enough body count and gore should convince parents to leave the kids at home - even though the violence comes in a frequently comic PG-13 CGI-style.
At times The Shack is able to provoke real thought and introspection. But as a movie, it struggles with issues of structure and execution, which no doubt happened in the book-to-film transition.
Overall, Tim Timmerman: Hope of America is a quirky but flawed film that is headed in the right direction, just good enough to get you to look forward to the filmmaker's next effort.
A United Kingdom eventually settles for a modest spot on the good section of the quality spectrum.
Table 19 is a wedding movie for people who hate weddings, and an underdog movie for anyone who has ever felt life's wrath in a social setting.

Perhaps it is intentional, but "The Sense of an Ending" really does leave you with only a sense of completion. It is a thoughtful film, populated by a strong, watchable cast, but its cryptic story and detached pacing will likely polarize audiences.
Collide isn't bad so much as it is a routine, but it could have been a romp.
It is remarkable to see people who can be so happy in the midst of miserable circumstances. That's the inspiring takeaway from The Workers Cup.
Freeland's effort features some fun elements, a premise with potential and a pair of appealing performances from its leads.
Does a good job of tapping into the inherent hope of exploring outer space and providing a realistic examination of what it will require.
A vivid testimonial of the power of education.
movie_title: Tell Them We Are Rising: The Story of Black Colleges and Universities (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating examination of a piece of masterful cinema, but it is also a sobering examination of a film that took the industry, and the culture, down a much more graphic and explicit path.
Lister-Jones's film leaves the audience feeling like the third-wheel drummer.
Anyone who has seen Bill Murray's Groundhog Day will instantly recognize its similarities to Before I Fall. That doesn't have to be a bad thing, but in this case it is.
People of all backgrounds can find a useful message in Kennamer's film. There's not a lot of debate about the idea that we could all use a few more vegetables in our diets and a lot less junk food.
Even if the new Beauty and the Beast doesn't manage to improve on the old one, it does offer a quality spectacle worth seeing.
Fans of stop-motion animation will be pleased to know they have another gem on their hands. My Life as a Zucchini is a bit darker than your usual kids movie, but it is a wonderful thing to watch.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beyond a portrait of a reluctant friendship, Lady in the Van is also a kind statement on the power of patient charity and the challenge of forgiveness, especially when you are called to forgive yourself.

Born in China" may not inspire the merchandising juggernaut of some of Disney's other properties, but it is a fun, insightful and beautiful way to learn about a part of the world most will never see otherwise.
There's a fine line between homage and a lack of original ideas. Unfortunately Spark: A Space Tail falls on the latter side of the equation.
Too often, Connery's effort feels a little too easy to pass over.

With its subtle, artistic execution and poignant story, Frantz becomes a thoughtful reflection on the pain of war and the nature of forgiveness, even in the most extreme of circumstances. It's also a tragic reminder of how love can transcend deep wounds.

Its most impressive feat may be how, for all of its mayhem, The Fate of the Furious still manages to finish with a positive message about family. That's one rule these movies never seem willing to break.
Gifted is the moving and resonant story of a brilliant child trapped in a custody battle between two relatives.

The Case for Christ still has its weaknesses, and even the faithful might feel that a secular inquiry into the evidence of Christ's Resurrection is kind of missing the point. But as a film, it is a sure step in a positive direction.

It still features a talented cast and professional production, but a half-baked theme and low-conflict plot leave the movie feeling bland and forgettable, as hard to distinguish as its primary characters.
Your Name is a remarkably bland title for a pretty interesting movie, but Shinkai's effort - based on his own original novel - is a curious blend of two complex genres that elevates both.

At 11 p.m. on cable, or even at the dollar theater, a reunion special can be perfectly good. But like the bank job their onscreen characters are struggling to pull off, Going in Style feels like a film that is just beyond salvaging.

Boss Baby does have some nice moments, and it manages to draw some laughs. Things eventually work around to that accepting-a-sibling big picture, which is nice. But Boss Baby is a step down from the better animation efforts out there.
The Zookeeper's Wife may not rank with the best of its genre, but as a unique perspective on the Holocaust, it is a moving celebration of the people who fought against it.
Whether Ghost in the Shell's story is faithful or not, it feels empty, and the final product feels like a missed opportunity.
There's some humor, and there's some action, but the style feels like any other 2017 sci-fi action film.
It's good enough to provoke thought.

On its own, Masterminds is a decent comedy, even if everyone involved has done better work elsewhere. But next to all the serious options playing in theaters right now, Masterminds may be just the goofy change of pace you need.
The payoff just isn't there.
Altogether, Hancock and Keaton have created a very well-told and well-acted film, but The Founder will leave you with a bad taste in your mouth.
Loving is a low-key movie about a low-key couple whose actions proved to be anything but.
The Potter imagination is also on full display, mostly through the introduction of Scamander's myriad beasts, which blend familiar physical characteristics with human foibles.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Almost Christmas also follows that oft-tried but rarely true formula of the ensemble comedy, whereby a half-dozen storylines are crammed into a single feature film in the hopes of covering as much thematic ground as possible.
Long Way North is a charming and simple feature that mines themes of family and determination in the midst of challenging trials.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This darker side of the man who became known as the "Galloping Grandfather" in the 1970s lends a bitter taste to the sweetness of director Ron Davis' documentary, but it also gives it a more honest and human feel.
In the realm of big screen science fiction, "Arrival" feels like a mix of 2001: A Space Odyssey with a generous dose of Close Encounters of the Third Kind.
As a portrait of an era that Beatty lived and worked through, Rules Don't Apply has a poetic charm, even if its final takeaway feels a bit more ambiguous.
While about 60 percent of Trolls is a solid, quality production, the rest is an acquired taste that will polarize the audience, especially those on the mature end.

Sadly, a couple of major plot twists take an already complicated plot and render it nearly incomprehensible, turning Inferno into a simple movie that is made complicated simply for the sake of being complicated.

The result is a fun and manic film that - while definitely earning its PG-13 rating -- fills that rare contemporary void between comedies that are aimed at little kids and those that are stuffed with raunchy R-rated content.

It may not have the shoulders to carry the expectations of a summer blockbuster, but it's a solid action option as a break from the Halloween frights and based-on-a-true-story dramas that will be filling screens until the holiday season kicks in.

It may not measure up to the Twelve Angry Men heights of the genre, but for those with any interest in the fundamentals of argument, the legal system or the frailty of belief, Denial is worth consideration.
If you're determined to head to the theater for a fright this Halloween, Origin of Evil will provide a scare or two. But you'd be a lot better off watching one of the real classics at home.
It would be easy to dismiss Middle School's faulty internal logic and argue that it's a movie for kids, played from the kids' perspective, but the kids deserve better.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the story behind the curtain can't quite equal the visual spectacle, Doctor Strange will put a smile on the faces of casual and hardcore fans alike.
Director Billy Dickson's Christmas movie means well, but a muddled story and some flawed writing keep "Believe" from achieving its goals.
Director Brad Peyton may have wrapped up his film in the trappings of demonic possession, but inside that packaging is a watered-down "Inception" laced with a mild horror aftertaste.
As a prequel, it brings depth and strength to the existing canon, and Rogue One: A Star Wars Story will probably leave fans wishing it could have spun off into a franchise of its own.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Lipitz gives] us an intimate view of the girls' day-to-day lives and reminds us that even though her subjects have noble intentions, they are still kids and flawed human beings.
Somehow this off-brand Fast and Furious makes Vin Diesel's flagship franchise feel restrained, intelligent and believable by comparison.

Regardless of how you feel about the ending, though, most will note a tour de force performance from McAvoy, who is often called to transition between characters on a dime and easily proves to be the highlight of the film.

While the wide-eyed dog narrator device is cute, it also creates some narrative problems. Hallström's protagonist is often along for the ride on a story that is low on conflict, even if it's high on "aw, shucks" moments.
The film's biggest weakness may be its namesake, essentially a guy in white makeup and a hooded coat who hangs around with a badly rendered CGI monster dog.
Berg's primary accomplishment is his ability to create tension and suspense in a story that everyone already knows.
We learn about a largely unknown venue of the civil rights movement, but we also gain a general appreciation for the Herculean task of getting the Mercury astronauts into space at all.
A Monster Calls builds to a moving finale that is much more spiritual and emotional than action-packed.
A riveting meditation on pride, family and personal weakness. It's not the kind of film you forget easily.
Lion is not an easy journey, but it is a thoughtful, worthwhile and ultimately inspiring experience.

The movie looks cool, and if you can lose yourself in the thunderous soundtrack and the various action scenes, you might be OK. But once you start trying to connect the dots, you'll probably be better off going back to the game.
Where the best animated features blend story, craft and wit in a way that appeals to the parents and the kids, Sing lags a step or two behind.
It is a gorgeous movie to watch, but an experience that ultimately feels unsatisfying.
As fun as that opening scene may be, the story that follows is what makes "La La Land" a great movie.

Frankel overcooked some nice raw ingredients. The all-star cast is certainly giving their best, especially Smith...But the noble performances aren't enough to overcome the weaknesses of the story or the miscalculation of the tone.
The film is never allowed to breathe. It's rushed, and it's a shame.
As faith-based films go, Risen is one of the better ones.
It's a poetic statement, but the reason the music and the man stick with us is because they inspire us to work harder at whatever we are doing, regardless of whether it can be played on a piano.
Fresh and bubbling with personality in places, but lacking that final piece that will bring the picture together.
Is it still fun? Yes. Is it indulgent? Absolutely.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't deliver as many "wow" moments as one might hope for, but as far as the X-Men franchise is concerned, it's one of the better installments.
Christopher S. Clark and Patrick Henry Parker's new film offers a powerful lesson on the nature of forgiveness.
movie_title: Just Let Go: A Night Of Forgiveness (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Shot on location in Nepal, director Rick McFarland might have given viewers a silent sequence of dramatic landscapes and called it good. But the film's story reflects that same dichotomy and leaves you with a subtle message to ponder.
Through interviews and file footage, Fetisov becomes the human protagonist at the heart of a story that says as much about the USSR as it does about hockey.
Tomorrowland makes for a fun and exciting adventure.
[Spielberg] strikes a seasoned balance of tension, action and wit that keeps the film moving at just the right pace.
The Witch has the distinction of a well-made film that is exactly what it wants to be, but is also too intense to recommend in good conscience.

To Damon's credit, it takes a special kind of actor to anchor this kind of movie, and his personality goes a long way to maintain The Martian's fun factor. But some of Damon's most effective moments come as Watney is combating discouragement.
As a cinematic experience, The Walk is one of those films that justifies the larger-than-life Hollywood experience and reminds us how much fun it can still be to go to the movies.

The Intern is a two-hour footrace between emotion-yanking charm and utter predictability. There is never any doubt as to what this film is going to serve you. The only question is how much you enjoy the recipe.

Kormákur gives us just enough about his various characters to care about them, and immerses his audience so fully in the experience that it's easy to sympathize even without a lot of character development.
It's still exciting and well produced, but it's not as compelling.
There are still plenty of fun moments, but a positive experience with Genisys will require moderated expectations.
People of religious faith -- LDS Church members in particular -- will likely be disturbed to see how Jeffs was able to distort familiar doctrines into such awful ends.
A study of pure, selfless love and how it can be expressed when the usual channels have been painfully withdrawn.
Minions is a fun backstory for a popular group of sidekicks, but it really shouldn't extend beyond that. It does a good job with what it has, but it won't leave you asking for more.
It's a decent idea that was overwhelmed by excess story and excess effects. Jupiter may be ascending, but its audience will leave shrugging.
It's a routine documentary about a fascinating man, albeit one with a great classic rock soundtrack.
City of Z is an interesting reminder of the peril that made civilization possible.
Me and Earl has a powerful, moving and aching heart at its center. It's not a textbook "coming of age" film, but it is a magnificent essay on the nature and value of friendship.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Selma is an interesting and engaging glimpse of the civil rights movement at one of its most powerful moments. It won't be the civil rights movie to define all civil rights movies, but it carries a worthwhile message.
The result is a very human portrayal of an exotic industry and an honest portrait of an accomplished man confronting serious stress with the help of a dedicated team.

There are times during The DUFF where you sense some potential. But by the time the third act delivers its predictable finale, seasoned audiences are left to reminisce about the movies that did it all better.
Alive Inside is a worthwhile reminder that life is a beautiful thing, and that something as simple as music can unlock the life within our most isolated peers.
Non-Stop still offers a decent ride. Just be ready to shrug off a few cringe-worthy moments.

Fed Up is a documentary about choice and accountability, but it's awfully picky about whose choice and whose accountability are to be evaluated. The result is a documentary about sugar that should probably be taken with a grain of salt.
Mr. Peabody & Sherman is a well-made film that carries a broad appeal.
Secret of the Tomb feels a little lightweight on the story end. Most of the narrative is pretty linear, and it feels even thinner than its 90-minute run time.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The telling instead of showing makes it hard to get emotionally invested in what's going on.
The Final Girls is a fun and surprisingly sweet send-up of one of Hollywood's most tedious and celebrated genres: the slasher film.
In his book Outliers, Malcolm Gladwell suggests that it takes about 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in your field. Jem and the Holograms figures it takes about a month.
The Last Witch Hunter isn't really scary or exciting or engaging. It's not quite bad, but it isn't good either.
As a visual experience, many of the animated sequences are beautiful. But, without the focus of a traditional screenplay, the story drags a bit and even feels tedious.
It doesn't help that the acting and writing is often clunky, making it that much harder to suspend disbelief in a genre that insists on doing just that.
The acting is solid on all counts, but Dunagan really makes things work, hitting just the right mark of ambiguity for Nana to keep things going.
The movie becomes more problematic when we try to discern how director Ken Loach wants us to apply its lessons to our day.
Some of the complexity will probably be lost on younger viewers, but the story itself is entertaining enough to keep the kids' attention.
Like the first film, what makes the sequel work is how director Joss Whedon builds the action on this character foundation and injects it with just enough humor to make its personality radiate.
It's a nice family-friendly flick that balances some zany visual comedy against an understated British sense of humor.
It's definitely an acquired taste, but it's most helpful to view the film as a fairy tale.
It's a fun summer ride, but it won't keep you coming back over and over.
Shaun the Sheep is another great marriage of sly British wit and the character of stop-motion animation.
You want to like the results, but most of the time, the zany circumstances and physical comedy feel too forced.
It's a great character sketch, but it's not character-driven. It's war-driven, and that may be its main point.
Life is a mess. Aloha is a moving film about a man who is trying to decide whether to clean his life up.
Even if the humor is a little too smart and a tad too vulgar for the G-rated crowd, Penguins should still be a safe option for the whole family.
Even though Need for Speed manages to entertain in some of its best moments, the final product is just too bloated and inept to work.
Sound City is a fun ride for diehard fans of most any brand of rock and roll.
The outcome of that game will give audiences plenty of material for moral debates in the weeks to come, and maybe a sequel down the road.
While Jackson has clearly fleshed out some aspects of the source material, An Unexpected Journey doesn't drag nearly as much is its 169-minute running time might suggest.
Guardians of the Galaxy may be the most unique film to come out of the Marvel stable so far. If the oppressive weight of late summer has you down, this movie may be just the thing you need.

As a movie experience, Pixels is a little like fishing the marshmallows out of your Lucky Charms. Take out a couple good jokes and some computer-generated-imagery action and you're stuck with a lot of bland, soggy filler.
It's a good documentary, and it should be a perfect choice when it shows up on your Netflix menu, but it's nowhere near a great one.
The humor keeps things light and sincere but never distracts.
Once I Was a Beehive is a film that benefits greatly from its core casting. Both Warner and Smith are strong in their roles, pushing past easy characterizations to bring out some very honest moments.

Z puts a lot of moral questions on the table, but doesn't provide much in the way of answers. Ambiguity can be a powerful thing in film, but Z becomes a thoughtful exercise where it could have been a resonant experience.
Still Alice is not an easy film to watch, but it is a movie well worth seeing.
It's thoughtful, natural and often very funny and relatable.
Can you really call a film bad if it achieves exactly what it sets out to achieve?
Earthquakes hit California, and The Rock teams up with his estranged wife to save their daughter. That's pretty much it, and that's all there really needs to be.
Sponge Out of Water strikes an effective balance between goofball humor that will entertain the kids and adult-targeted humor of a more wink-wink nature.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For about 20 minutes, Poltergeist gave you the feeling that you're in for a fun time. But fun turned into routine way too fast.
Thanks to the candid quality of those recordings and some excellent production from Riley, Listen to Me Marlon is a powerful and insightful experience.
Just in case Tom Cruise and Daniel Craig aren't your cup of super spy tea, The Man from U.N.C.L.E. arrives this weekend on a wave of style that will make you wish it were 1963 all over again.
If there's a plus side, the effects aren't too bad, and there is some genuine talent in the cast. But it's wasted on a movie that stumbles all over itself.

Even if it's a B-side, Ricki and the Flash will be worth seeing for Meryl Streep fans, music fans and, especially, anyone who's ever spent time in a working-class band. Sometimes it's the deep cuts you remember the best.
Warts and all, Cruise has delivered another awesome Mission: Impossible spectacle that should keep the summer of 2015 going strong for at least a few more weeks.
It won't rewrite the book on horror movies, but it offers a fun chapter.
Ant-Man is this year's Guardians of the Galaxy. It focuses on a peripheral, wisecracking member of the Marvel Universe, adding a generous dose of humor to its superhero action.
Phoenix has a plot that hangs on the edge of believability but injects enough tension at the right moments to keep the film from tripping over itself.
Race is a collection of good parts that make up a decent whole.
The sum total is an interesting true-life story that just doesn't make for a great movie. Desert Dancer has its moments, but it feels like a story that was better lived than re-told.
The Lazarus Effect is a scary movie that pokes around with some big questions, but never really goes far enough to say anything.
"Daddy's Home" delivers a fun setup and a handful of exclamation points but fails to deliver on its potential.

The Road Chip is the cinematic equivalent of an air ball. It doesn't matter how pretty your form is or how expensive your shoes are; if you're aiming the ball at the wrong target, the result is going to look really, really bad.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ford especially earns his money with this one. But as fun as it is to see Han Solo back in action, the newcomers like Ridley take center stage, launching subplots that should be fun to watch in ensuing installments.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, it's a dramatic and harrowing tale, and Howard packs in enough impressive visuals to justify a big-screen IMAX experience.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Davis deserves credit for putting a unique spin on a well-trod formula. But aside from a handful of high points, Christmas Eve only proves that like Christmas itself, a lot of something doesn't always add up to a good something.
Her work made her one of the most celebrated figures of the 20th century, but The Letters is far too preoccupied with the bureaucratic minutiae of her journey.
As talented as they may be physically, Bracey and Ramirez are no onscreen match for Reeves and Swayze, and the plot and dialogue aren't helping.
It definitely could have been better, but can we really gripe about a Christmas movie about a vengeful goat monster from the underworld?

It's easy to imagine an inventive take on a Jurassic World here. But The Good Dinosaur takes a different path, and plays like a prehistoric mix tape, mashing up familiar and not-so-familiar characters in a way that feels more curious than clever.
In spite of a star-studded Hollywood cast, Secret manages to clothesline itself on an unsatisfying twist ending.
The final Hunger Games movie should have been triumphant. Instead, Mockingjay - Part 2 finishes with the resignation of a teenager who has finally been nagged into cutting the grass.

There are plenty of characters and plenty of action to go around, yet thanks to its strong sense of suspense, Catching Fire doesn't feel as long as its near-two-and-a-half-hour running time might suggest.
When your protagonist is watching the third act of your movie play out on a TV monitor, you should know you have a problem.
You will not love the Coopers. You won't even like them.
Better to be an overachieving B-movie than a disappointing headliner.
"Concussion" gives audiences some sobering things to ponder.
"Joy" is a fascinating journey celebrating the American dream while making compelling comments on feminism, capitalism and the long-suffering love of family.
It won't make you lose any sleep when the night comes.
Sadly, like Anchorman 2 and Dumb and Dumber To, Zoolander 2 is another argument against waiting a decade before producing a sequel for a popular comedy.
The Fundamentals of Caring is a solid buddy movie that uses some genuinely funny moments to underscore a poignant message about friendship and dealing with the cards life has dealt you.
It's very difficult to find a positive to take from the Norm of the North experience, and it's unlikely anyone will decipher its muddled eco-friendly message from all the chaos.
A portrait of a beloved decade, an essay on the struggles of a family and evidence of how good music can be silly and sublime at the same time.
Herzog's wit has an amusing way of holding his documentary together.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A stylistic and creative extension of a unique franchise.
Disney's role in the lives of children around the world is indisputable, but the company would be hard-pressed to find a better example to be proud of than the autistic subject of Life, Animated.
It's a fun story arc, and Aisholpan is a sweet protagonist who is easy to cheer for.
The Boy isn't scary, and director William Brent Bell doesn't do near enough elsewhere to make up for it.
A solid movie about a remarkable true story.
Surreal, sweet and frequently head-shaking.
Feels more like the first draft of what will eventually become a much better movie.
It mines a number of familiar tropes, but combined with poor execution, the result is a recipe for disaster and not the cool postapocalyptic kind.
"Mustang" wants to send a message about old world patriarchal cultures, and it stumbles over itself to get there.
"In Jackson Heights" gives its residents a voice, but it doesn't really help their argument.
Altogether, The Imitation Game is a film that will give you plenty to think about.
Painting Wilson in such a light may compromise the objectivity of Love & Mercy, but the film's strengths easily outweigh its few weaknesses.

Mulligan does an excellent job as Maud. She's perfect for this kind of role, and her transformation is convincing. It will be a surprise if she doesn't see some kind of nomination in the coming months.
Even if the execution and the characters are too flawed for their own good, Miss You Already has some important things to say about the ravages of cancer and the trials of womanhood.
The Salt of the Earth should be required viewing for anyone with a serious interest in photography, and it will move those without one.
Chuck Norris has a lot going for it, but its most powerful effect is to remind us of the simple freedoms we enjoy.
It makes for a film that is beautiful to watch and interesting to think about if taken with the right grain of salt.
A few flashes of genuine wit are almost enough to cover for the lack of plot, but not enough to distract audiences from a bloated run time and a mean-spirited sense of humor.
When Marnie Was There is a very sweet and unassuming film and is a far cry from most of today's animated options.
Insurgent wants us to be awestruck, but in spite of a few nice ingredients, we've seen it before, and we've seen it better.

Maggie probably won't make anyone's list of all-time zombie classics, but it helps to diversify what can be a redundant genre. It's an interesting change of pace for its cast and a fun - if bleak - offering for zombie fans.

Somehow the narrative holds together, and some sincere moments offset the feeling of bloat that sets in over the film's two hours. It's hard to complain too much about seeing the likes of Nighy and Dench in action.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film has its moments but not enough to justify a trip to the multiplex.
Woman in Gold gives the audience a lot to think about, even if it isn't easy to watch. Though it hinges on the atrocities of the Holocaust, its darkness is much more cerebral and worth considering.
A comparatively simple story may keep Timbuktu from reaching all-time status in films of its type, but it is still a film worth seeing.
Self/less gets an A for concept and a C for execution. By sacrificing character and believability for action, director Tarsem Singh dumbs down what could have been a compelling sci-fi flick.

The key to enjoying Seventh Son is to keep modest expectations. And, in this case, "modest expectations" probably means you're better off saving your first-run dollars and waiting for cheaper options.
It's bleak and beautiful at the same time.
The misadventures of this odd couple manage to deliver some laughs, some obvious moral lessons and, yes, lots of musical segues scored with Rihanna tracks.
Overall, it's a pretty dull date night for all interested parties.

It's this up-close-and-personal photography style that makes Monkey Kingdom and the other Disneynature films so effective. It's impossible to watch the results without constantly contemplating the process it took to get the footage.
The twists and turns may feel a little forced, and a few moments might even be shocking. But Little Boy squeezes the most it can from a quality cast and the best of intentions.
In short, longtime fans should be happy with the result, and new fans will find an easy time getting on board.
In better hands, Seoul Searching might have been a nice balance of '80s nostalgia and sincere coming of age. Unfortunately, what we have here is a missed opportunity.
At 105 minutes, that deliberate pace ultimately undermines Kumiko's impact, and an ambiguous ending may leave a lot of audiences wondering what message they were supposed to take from the experience.
The little girls who fill theater seats in their princess dresses will still have a great time.
Like the best sports movies, McFarland, USA makes sure the action on the field is only one part of the cinematic spectrum. And in this case, it's a spectrum worth seeing.
Maybe every time-travel movie can't use a souped-up DeLorean, but Project Almanac may leave you wanting to pull out your old copy of Back to the Future instead.
Overall, the documentary is well made and well executed, and it tells a compelling story. But its greatest strength may be its own honesty.
For audiences looking for a family friendly piece of animation that eschews the mainstream, this film is a nice option.
In total, Freetown delivers a powerful message despite limited means, and marks another success for an emerging filmmaker.

Kenner's sympathies are clear - "Don't let them stack the deck!" the film proclaims - and ultimately Merchants of Doubt does a much better job of making you think than convincing you of what to think.
It's a thoughtful, beautifully shot film that respects its characters.
Adaline is well served by its screenplay, which takes opportunities to wink at the audience without turning the film into slapstick.
If you can forgive the soap opera story, Madding Crowd is a beautiful film, making the most of its striking British landscapes.
Don Verdean probably won't replace Napoleon Dynamite on the list of cinematic accomplishments for Team Hess, but it's a worthy entry to a unique portfolio.
Max is much more interested in action than character development. The sad result is a noble film that starts strong but quickly circles the drain by the end of its 111-minute run time.
Spectre doesn't offer much in the way of new material, but in a series known for its iconic tropes, the challenge is making the familiar feel fresh. Spectre mines those tropes well.
After the Storm is a sad but insightful story about a father trying to reconcile his mistakes.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If you're trying to pull a coherent message from the movie's web of tragedy, romance and human weakness, you may wind up scratching your head.
The film definitely has its moments, and at arm's length, The Promise will resonate. But overall, it feels like a missed opportunity, a good film that could have been much better.
Balancing wit and romance against a life-or-death drama can be a tricky balance. Their Finest stumbles a little around the middle, but recovers well enough to produce a satisfying film.
Audiences from outside the LDS Church may not come away with a new understanding of church positions on contemporary social issues, but at least they might find their basic assumptions challenged.
It's possible that Shelton put a little too much faith in Knightley's charm, and you can't really blame her.
The ultimate result may be kind of predictable, but it's still fun.
If it wasn't for a mess of a third act, Age of Extinction might have been a half-decent movie.
Divergent may not be the most popular thrill in the theme park, but it could have been a lot worse, and you'll probably be up for a second spin.
The Void often seems too concerned with its uplifting message that's obvious to the audience, where more subtlety and a "show, don't tell" method might have resonated with more power.

It's a great option if you're looking for something with a stronger spiritual foundation than a lot of what is currently in theaters, but it will probably strengthen beliefs more than it will expand them.
The best way to approach "Exodus" may be with measured expectations. It's fun and exciting, but not mind-blowing. Critical, but faithful.
It's very easy to imagine the story on stage, but the transition to film maintains a powerful degree of intimacy.

The entire production is chock-full of campy humor and visual charm that should appeal to a variety of audiences, but parents may decide Boxtrolls is a little too creepy for the youngest of the young.
Interstellar is why we go to the movies.
Anyone who hides behind the "chick flick" defense on this one is kidding themselves. The Best of Me is a contrived manipulation and an insult to female sensibilities.
Humor and story aside, the biggest draw here is the impressive animation.
The breakout star here is Nelson, who practically forces a smile on your face at regular intervals.

The bottom line is that if you focus on its message, The Giver has some very important things to say. You just might find yourself a little frustrated with the information you get (or rather, don't get) along the way.
Even non-fans will get a thrill or two, followed by a quick laugh and a feeling like someone is trying to insult their intelligence.
Iron Man 3 may not feel as incomplete as a Gene Simmons solo record, but it does leave you wishing the rest of the band had come along for the ride.
There's plenty here to keep the kids happy, if only because the film employs Gru's seemingly innumerable yellow minions as a constant source of slapstick humor.
The fact that this "love" is really little more than lust and rebellion is ignored by everyone involved - though at least the lust waits until marriage to be consummated.
