The filmmaking and performances in Allied are both capable. The problem lies in the story (or lack thereof) and its execution.
Man Down tackles this monumental problem, only to fail as both entertainment and as a conversation starter.
There are plenty of chuckles sprinkled throughout the bloated running time of Why Him?, but it never finds that sublime sweet spot where the chuckles become sustained laughs.
It's too grimy and relentlessly bleak to be any fun, and lacks the substance and drama to be taken seriously.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's likely that the makers of Collateral Beauty were sincere in their objectives, but that certainly didn't translate to a final product that nauseates and manipulates in equal measure.
The Magnificent Seven is an unapologetic crowd pleaser, filled with daring anti-heroes, thrilling shootouts, and bloody gallows humor.
SHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock is a loving tribute to the talented artist who not only photographed sex, drugs, and rock 'n' roll, he lived it.
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though Phillips' triumphant performance makes The Night Stalker worth watching, it barely scratches the surface of Richard Ramirez's infectious evil.

It's admirable that Gray aspires to a more traditional epic rather than a simplistic actioner, but he fails to find the core of a story cluttered with romance, politics, warfare, sexism, racism, classism - and possibly more 'isms' than we've realized yet.

Though they only share a few scenes, watching Hanks and Streep perform is like watching two jazz musicians improvising together; overlapping chatter giving way to strategic silence with only the slightest of nonverbal cues.
Ultimately, what Anderson has given us is the best dramatic film of 2017. Phantom Thread is a haunting and exquisite treatise on the complexity of love.
If Star Wars: The Last Jedi isn't a complete deconstruction of the original trilogy, it's at least an acknowledgement that these archetypical characters must evolve in order to survive.
Alexander Payne will do good work again, but Downsizing is more than a tiny blemish on his resume.
Lauren Greenfield's stinging indictment of greed and excess also packs an unexpected emotional wallop.

It's unlikely that devotees will consider The Fate of the Furious one of the stronger entries in the series. Still, the filmmakers and actors are clearly dedicated to making a quality product, avoiding the complacency that often plagues action sequels.
Leave No Trace is a powerful statement about devotion, survival, and the interconnected threads that shape a society.

Your heart absolutely aches for Kayla, who is an adorable bundle of mumbles and stutters around her peers. As an adult observer, you know that Kayla will be okay, but those days seem fantastically improbable from her vantage point.
It's the type of outrageous ending that divides audiences and builds cult followings. Summer of '84 is a trashy classic that will absolutely rock midnight movie houses.
If only for a few hours, this documentary proves that human kindness can be contagious.

Powerful statements are made about racial identity, as well as facilitating and profiting from slavery by more fortunate members of the victimized group. Sorry to Bother You is a film with something important to say and it says the hell out of it.
We enjoy spending time with these characters, but the script needs to be leaner and less self-indulgent. When things finally click into gear, however, Blindspotting is relentless.
This story has more twists and turns than a second-rate soap opera.
Regardless of your political ideology, you'll come away with a newfound respect for the tireless pioneer of gender equality.
Ultimately, Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot is a frustrating tweener. It's not funny enough to keep you smiling, insightful enough to make you think, or sensational enough to shock you.
movie_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Juliet, Naked is a surprisingly pedestrian affair. The lack of humor or tension traces back to a love triangle that falls utterly flat.
A vivid portrait of artistic integrity and complete commitment to the art of filmmaking.

Anyone who has ever buried a parent or grandparent understands the soul-crushing process of re-visiting a loved one's trash and treasure. 306 Hollywood tackles this thankless task with reverence, humor, and an almost scholastic zeal.
The Zellner Brothers, David and Nathan, deliver plenty of quirk but little punch in this frontier tale filled with reprobates, rascals, and one adorable mini-horse named Butterscotch.
Leave No Trace is a powerful statement about devotion, survival, and the interconnected threads that shape a society.
An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn is a stylistic exercise in unpleasantness. There's an audience that enjoys such torture, but I'm not among their ranks.
movie_title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly this is a dumb comedy filled with characters who don't exist beyond the boundaries of this dumb story. The laughs are there, though, and if you keep your expectations low, you won't get too bored at this Game Night.
Annihilation is a visceral cinematic experience that, while plagued with structural problems, delivers plenty of thrills and eye-popping spectacle.
What ultimately makes Francis Lawrence's twisted tale of sexual gamesmanship worthwhile is the fearlessness of its leading lady and its uncanny ability to feel both cold and erotic at the same time.
DuVernay clearly wants to show us a good time, but a guiding artistic vision never materializes.
Perhaps the greatest compliment one can pay Franco's The Disaster Artist is that it encourages audiences to laugh with Wiseau and his clueless cohorts rather than mock them.
If McDonagh's dark comedy-drama doesn't quite out-Fargo Fargo, it brilliantly illustrates the chaos a few choice words can cause in the hands of a talented filmmaker.

[Reed] Morano made her bones as a cinematographer and it really shows in I Think We're Alone Now. She delights in a world without electricity, where she's free to illuminate her characters and interiors with luxurious natural light.
The God of Thunder removes the giant hammer from his backside and drops his stodgy pretentions in favor of having a good time.

Colossal mixes metaphor, dark comedy, and tragedy into a powerful statement about the nature of addiction. Though it staggers a bit in the middle, this is a poignant film that never preaches, often inspires, and always fascinates.
The Promise means well and perhaps it will open the eyes of a few uninformed audience members, but its lackluster love story will likely put off more people than it inspires.
A $100 million, obscenely fun superhero movie packed with amazing visuals, groovy tunes, wacky action, and unapologetic schmaltz.

Adding a convoluted mythology about the Xenomorph origins doesn't equate to scares, excitement, or entertainment value. There's simply no reason for this film to exist, regardless of its fleeting visual pleasures. This ship has definitely sailed.

With no interesting characters to lean on, Rønning and Sandberg need lots of imaginative action set pieces to provide any thrills. Sadly, the action is generic and drags on for far too long, which doesn't help the already lethargic pacing.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As if watching listless characters exchange infantile monologues isn't bad enough, the "villain of the week" is a complete bore.
A wise man once said, "Only a fool would make a campy horror movie into a serious drama." Actually, no one ever said that, but they should have, preferably on Tom Cruise's voicemail.
It's difficult to recall a film soaring so high, only to crash beneath the weight of its own narrative and thematic blunders.
Perhaps the greatest virtue of War for the Planet of the Apes is that it captures the futility of war without ever glamorizing the abhorrent carnage.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Baby Driver is an immersive thriller that seduces you to embrace its ridiculously fun excesses.
This is a lighthearted lark that functions as both a standalone feature, as well as an endlessly entertaining entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
It's a benign horror movie for grandma and her teenage grandkids to watch at the Cineplex on a lazy Sunday afternoon. Everyone else should avoid it like a demented musical Chinese wishing box.

Perhaps it's a case of honoring the literary source material too much, as War Machine fundamentally fails as compelling cinema. It's not smart enough to be a think piece and not visceral enough to evoke anger.

By the time the action finally arrives in the film's second half, you no longer care. Any energy you might have invested in this ugly world filled with shallow characters has been squandered on silly spy plots and shoddy storytelling.
Arguably Nolan's best film, Dunkirk is a propulsive descent into Hell that celebrates the indomitable human spirit.
Baffling and frustrating in equal measure, it's difficult to judge who Suburbicon was made for and impossible to imagine who will actually like it.

A firecracker first half eventually fizzles, as things take a melodramatic turn in the film's final act, but this is a clever and provocative look at love, sexuality, and the lies that preserve our fragile happiness.
It's a shame that Battle of the Sexes feels like little more than a primer to a different, more fascinating film.
If Adam Sandler ever did a remake of Die Another Day, it would probably look something like Kingsman: The Golden Circle.
The initial trepidation surrounding Blade Runner 2049 should be replaced by relief and exhilaration, as it's now clear that Villeneuve was the right man to helm such a risky project.
It's an unfocused hodgepodge of ineffective scenes and conflicting tones that disintegrates into an unsatisfying pile of... blah.
Good Time is the sleazy friend that knows all the best dives.

Soderbergh... remains a talented filmmaker with an instinctive gift for pacing and style. Cinephiles can rejoice that his self-imposed retirement seems to be over, even if he doesn't push himself too hard in this modest return.
There are crowd pleasers, and then there is Step.
The Dark Tower certainly flirts with plunging into entertaining schlock territory, but it's in too much of a hurry to indulge those tendencies.
This is a psychological and allegorical powerhouse that attacks your sensibilities with evocative imagery and rich symbolism.
A moderate success for those with low quality standards.
There is enough ability here for sure to make this worth a look. But somewhere between page and screen, whatever it was that attracted all that talent has evaporated into the night.
It's a more than reasonable effort especially given the meagre resources, making far more of itself than any number of similarly budgeted features. Worth a look.

Perhaps less celebrated and well-remembered than the earlier Brabourne and Goodwin Christie adaptations beginning with Murder on the Orient Express in 1974, Evil Under the Sun is easily their equal and possibly even the best of them.
For the more hard-line Christie aficionados, Hamilton's film is likely to be just a little too casual in its adaptation. For the less discriminating, it's a blast.
In spite of some fairly middling song writing and relatively average animation, if you're in the right frame of mind Rock Dog is actually rather a blast.
This is confused and heavy-going, and thanks to its 'Part one of two' nature rather unsatisfying.
What's remarkable is in how well achieved the extra-terrestrial intruder is, when we finally meet it face to tentacle.

The Howling is Network meets The Island of Dr Moreau, a treatise on nature versus nurture that isn't afraid to poke fun at its practitioners, and while it's not as entertaining as American Werewolf, in the final reckoning it is in many ways ... superior.
As usual the low budget archive sound and picture issues are but tiny niggles, when placed beside the value and enjoyment offered up by such a tremendous and truly essential collection of interviews.

It is a relatively good-looking film that doesn't outstay its welcome, however, one not to avoid rather than one to seek out. We definitely recommend you take your inner three-year-old along if you do, though.
The fantastical landscape of the film is also forgiving of its flaws, as any shortcomings in the script or direction simply feed into the sense of things being not as they should be.
This is ultimately an interesting and pretty but rather vacuous failure.
Better to either wallow in the nostalgia, or boggle at the ham-fistedness of it all.
Edwards doesn't quite possess the gravitas necessary to authenticate the end of the world, but he holds Miracle Mile together amiably enough, such that we do actually care what happens.

For the possible overuse of internal monologues and Julie Harris' overwrought but riveting performance as Eleanor, The Haunting still stands up as a relevant and effective study of both the psychology and parapsychology of its themes.
There are less productive ways to waste an hour and ten minutes of your time, but most of them involve wet paint that's already been applied.

There's promise here, but next time around Dee McLachlan needs to work out what kind of story she's telling and stick to the brief, rather than throwing the kitchen sink at the project in the hope enough will stick to have made it worthwhile.
Altogether anybody who enjoys a bit of screen martial arts won't be disappointed by a film that's probably destined to become something of a minor classic of the genre.
Not the most striking or memorable film, but effective nonetheless.
Aiming to be a synthesis of Wes Anderson and Richard Linklater, My Entire High School suffers from all of the issues that Anderson largely avoids.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Those who manage to make it through the cultural differences will find Monster Hunt a charming, emotionally engaging and moreover intelligent film, one which will handsomely repay their suspension of some admittedly quite wilful disbelief.
Make no mistake, this is not by any stretch of the imagination A Good Film. It is, however, surprisingly entertaining in all sorts of odd ways.
Almost every set or action or line of dialogue feels like the substandard equivalent of something you've seen or heard being done better elsewhere.
It's not overly engaging, and other than in its politics it doesn't say an awful lot.
It's a fascinating depiction of London at the turn of the 1960s, just before The Beatles arrived to turn the country on its head, and well worth a revisit in this glorious 4k restoration.
If you're an aficionado of this sort of thing, there will be nothing here to surprise you, but the mechanics of the movie will certainly entertain.
If you think it's just another Pixar film, then you're right, it absolutely is. And that's what makes it so wonderful and so worth having.
You get Disney-esque talking animals, a villain straight out of the Postman Pat movie, and resolutions it's impossible not to see coming the moment the title sequence fades out.

That is Roberts' biggest problem because in spite of managing to keep the obviously slight narrative ticking over such that it never gets excruciatingly dull, we never really get to care either - and thus the killer twist at the end is totally wasted.

Willy Rozier's film is a dreary production with a script and performances that most school plays would put to shame. Nevertheless, it does possess a weird kind of otherworldly charm, almost in spite of itself.
movie_title: The Girl in the Bikini (Manina, la fille sans voile) (1952)

movie_review_blurb: War for the Planet of the Apes manages a deft balance between allusion, esotericism, and obviousness that in part explains the runaway success of the series.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)
